inscription.text: S. Michele Arcangelo Protettore di Sala Consilina
[last line which is a verse] Baroz-e-Eid ham ko hasrat-e-didar baqi hai; Nahin nikli tamanna-e-wisal-e-yaar baqi hai

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: S. Michelle Arcangelo, Protettore di Sala Consilina

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: S. Michele Arcangelo Protettore di Sala Consilina
text-transcription-ur: [first line] Eid Mubarak
text-transcription-ur: [second line] Ya Rahim
text-transcription-ur: [last line which is a verse] Baroz-e-Eid ham ko hasrat-e-didar baqi hai; Nahin nikli tamanna-e-wisal-e-yaar baqi hai
explanatory comments/crosstagging: On this Eid Greetingcard, published by Hafiz Qamriddin & sons, we can the archangel Michael in the form of a statue. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: An Urdu message is printed on address side with a couplet talking of the desire to see the beloved on the day of Eid. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: It seems that such Eid cards have been created from blank picture cards imported in bulk from Europe. They feature photographs of locations and objects as alien to Indian Eid as Greek and Italian sculptures and monuments, besides European cinema and theatre stars of the time! (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)
related hyperlink: Saeed, Yousuf 2011. "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html last accessed 2011-04-04 (gs)

related hyperlink: Wehbe, Rana, Seeing Beirut through Colonial Postcards: A Charged Reality, (undated) American University of Beirut, Lebanon, http://webfea.fea.aub.edu.lb/proceedings/2004/SRC-ArD-01.pdf (gs)
